Partecipazione come relatore per la presentazione del paper dal titolo “Vocation vs. perceived image of cultural districts in heritage marketing” (coautori: G. Guido, A. Peluso, C. Pace) al Convegno Internazionale “1st International Tourist Forum on Tourism as an Opportunity for Recreation and a Chance for the Development of Regions”, Międzyzdroje (Polonia). 28- 30 maggio 2009. Abstract della ricerca: The present conceptual paper discusses the issue of perception of local territorial systems, the unit analysis of place marketing and, in particular, of a sub-category of these systems, the cultural districts, that is to say, those tourist districts that promote the cultural heritage of a territory. When, in fact, the identity of a district (i.e., its vocation) is not perceived through the image projected to its potential users, conflicts arise which require the intervention of the administrators/managers of place marketing to reduce the discrepancies between vocation and the perceived image and thus allowing the achievement of system developmental objectives. The present contribution is articulated as follows: the first section reviews the definitions of examined contrasts, with particular reference to those of local territorial systems (LTS, the unit of analysis for place marketing), districts (which represent an LTS category and typically differentiate themselves, according to their vocation, in industrial and tourist districts) and cultural districts (which are an evolution of tourist districts). The second section illustrates the heritage marketing characteristics; a place marketing approach applicable to the cultural districts, which differentiates itself from the mainstream place marketing for some specific employment and realization conditions. The third section examines those cases in which a marketing promoting the LTS development is faced with a concern relating to a discrepancy between the identity of a district, that is, its vocation, which derives from the heritage of peculiar resources belonging to development strategies, and the image as perceived by potential users. Finally the fourth section discusses operational strategies to reduce these discrepancies between vocation and image of cultural districts, in order to ultimately favour the development of local systems. Partecipazione come relatore per la presentazione del paper di ricerca dal titolo “Destination personality as a strategic construct for the development of districts’ image” (coautori: Gianluigi guido, Alessandro Peluso, Irene Prete, Cinzia Pace), al Convegno Internazionale “International Conference on Tourism Development and Management”, Kos, Grecia. 11-14 settembre 2009. Si allegano: - Certificato di partecipazione come relatore - Proceedings del Convegno con la pubblicazione del paper Abstract della ricerca: Heritage is the complex stock of what the past has left for us today, thereby defining the identity of a place, as well as of its population or a specific social group. Typical constituents of heritage are food products, environment, manufactured goods, architecture, history and myths that have come down to us and that we consider representative of the past with which we identify ourselves. The present conceptual paper takes into consideration as a unit of analysis the Local Territorial Systems (LTSs) and, in particular, the Cultural Districts, which represent one of the categories belonging to districts with a tourist vocation. Its purpose is to show how a necessary condition for territorial marketing strategies to succeed is the existence of a congruence between the identity of a specific LTS and its perceived image. The identity of an LTS is determined by the stock of resources and competences existing within the territory (a.k.a. internal potential), which characterizes the specific (either “industrial” or “tourist”) vocation that guides the strategic subject in the pursuit of a specific competitive advantages. The image of an LTS, as perceived by potential categories of customers and stakeholders in general (residents, tourists, firms and exporting markets), is based upon their expectancies (i.e., expectations and desires) and perceptions of their use experiences with the LTS. Potential discrepancies between LTS identity (objectively determined from existing resources and competences) and images (subjectively perceived depending on expectancies and experiences) – operazionalized through the perceived personality concept as adapted to places (destination personality) – could be overcome by implementing specific destination branding strategies. Success of heritage marketing strategies derives from the capacity of creating “packages of experiences” to offer for consumption. This means that the place marketer should offer specific scenarios, within which the use of places can take place, thus influencing consumers’ minds through specific communication strategies by projecting an image of the LTS congruent with its vocation, that is, the heritage of a territory.

Partecipazione come relatore per la presentazione del paper “Determinanti latenti nell’intenzione d’acquisto dei fashion luxury goods: un’indagine qualitativa di tipo laddering” (coautore: Gianluigi Guido), al VI Convegno Annuale della Società Italiana Marketing (SIM), Fashion Marketing, Università di Firenze, Firenze. 6-7 novembre 2009. Si allega: - Certificato di partecipazione come relatore - Programma del Convegno - Paper presentato Abstract della ricerca: Lo scopo della presente ricerca è investigare le determinanti latenti nell’intenzione d’acquisto dei prodotti moda di lusso. Un totale di quaranta soggetti, selezionati tra i consumatori di una boutique italiana specializzata in prodotti moda di lusso, sono stati esaminati attraverso interviste in profondità. La ricerca qualitativa è basata sulla raccolta di dati attraverso le tecniche del laddering e della catena mezzi-fini. I risultati preliminari hanno mostrato che i consumatori acquistano i prodotti moda di lusso principalmente per esprimere il proprio stile di vita e soddisfare valori personali. La hierarchical value map risultante dalla raccolta ed elaborazione dei dati dimostra che la sicurezza personale e l’auto-realizzazione rappresentano i valori finali latenti più rilevanti nell’acquisto ed nel consumo dei luxury goods. Le implicazioni manageriali sono legate alla possibilità di identificare prodotti, valori del brand e messaggi comunicazionali maggiormente coerenti con un consumo soggettivo, auto-gratificante ed interiorizzato.

Partecipazione come relatore per la presentazione del paper “The meanings of Fashion Luxury Goods: Externalized vs Internalized Consumption” (coautore: Gianluigi Guido), al Convegno Internazionale “International Conference on Global Fashion Marketing: Creative and Innovative Contexts”, Università di Firenze, Firenze, Italia. 9-11 novembre 2009. Abstract della ricerca: The luxury products market has grown significantly over the last decades, both because of the increased number of high-net-worth consumers and because of companies’ new and specific strategies for geographic outreach and product range. The objective of this study is to analyse the various meanings of luxury that emerge from the literature, highlighting in particular, in the approach to the consumption of luxury fashion goods, the dichotomy between “externalized luxury”, understood as a status symbol and “internalized luxury” meant instead as individual style. Regarding the externalized luxury, approaches to consumption linked to ostentation, materialism and superfluousness are identified and analyzed. The characteristics of luxury interpreted as lifestyle, emotions, culture, dreams and hedonism are also highlighted as they relate to internalized luxury. The managerial implications for marketers are related to the possibility to offer conceptualizations, information and models able to facilitate product decision-making and strategy planning, communication and branding oriented to targets of consumers characterized by a subjective and self-referenced approach to consumption. Partecipazione come relatore per la presentazione del paper dal titolo “Influence of Cognitive Age and Socio-Psychographics in the Purchasing of Luxury Goods by Elderly Consumers” (coautore: Gianluigi Guido) al Convegno Internazionale “International Marketing Trends Conference”, Università Ca’ Foscari, Venezia, Italia. 19-21 gennaio 2012. Si allega: - Certificato di partecipazione come relatore - Programma del Convegno - Paper presentato Abstract della ricerca: This study compares elderly consumers who consider luxury goods mainly as status symbols – a situation which is known as “externalized luxury” – with elderly consumers who, on the contrary, perceive luxury goods mainly as an expression of individual style – so-called “internalized luxury” (Amatulli and Guido, 2011). Their cognitive age is analyzed and, more in particular, their “youth age” (Barak and Gould, 1985) – i.e., the difference between their objective chronological age and the subjective cognitive age that they perceive when imagining themselves in different circumstances. An online survey with a sample of 619 Italian consumers aged 60 and over revealed that places, contexts and situations significantly influenced the cognitive age declared by participants and also point out the relative differences between the two segments of elderly consumers. Moreover, the socio-psycho-graphic differences between elderly consumers who buy luxury goods mainly for status, or mainly for individual lifestyle, are pointed out. The results provide implications for marketing managers of luxury companies, who need to better understand and reach older consumers. In particular, these findings can help luxury marketing managers in planning specific communication strategies aimed at improving the effectiveness of brand image among elderly consumers.

Accettazione del research paper dal titolo “Elderly Consumers and Cognitive Age Dimensions: The Influence of Hedonic/Utilitarian Contextual Factors on Perceived Youthfulness” (coautori: Gianluigi Guido, Alessandro M. Peluso, M. Irene Prete) al Convegno Internazionale “Royal Statistical Society International Conference”, Telford, Inghilterra. 3-6 settembre 2012. Abstract della ricerca: In affluent societies, the elderly market constitutes a rapidly expanding demographic segment with an increasing spending power. In this marketing scenario, understanding whether and to what extent both social and physical contexts affect elderly consumers’ cognitive age (i.e., how old individuals perceives themselves to be) and youthfulness perception (i.e., how young individuals feel themselves to be in comparison with their actual age) is important for both marketers and for researchers interested in improving the psychological well-being of this segment of consumers. The present study is the first investigation that explores how these two age-related constructs are affected by utilitarian versus hedonic circumstances. This study explores the context-dependency of cognitive age and perceived youthfulness, measured on a sample of 600 elderly consumers (60 years and older). Cognitive age measures were collected by asking respondents to report the age they would feel to have in different physical and social contexts, previously identified through focus groups. For each context, either utilitarian (e.g., “senior center”) or hedonic (e.g., “resort”) one, perceived youthfulness was obtained by subtracting the actual age from the cognitive age of respondents. Results of both ANOVA and t-test showed that the cognitive age and the related perceived youthfulness of elderly consumers significantly change as a function of context. More specifically, respondents reported that they felt much younger when they imagined themselves to be in hedonic contexts than in utilitarian ones (ps < .05). These findings may be of help to marketers who want to advertise products targeting older people. Results suggest that marketing processes usually applied to middle-aged markets could be applied to approach the ʽcognitively not-old consumer market’. Moreover, marketers can manage contextual factors – e.g., by using appropriate executional frameworks when developing advertising campaigns – in order to manipulate older consumers’ perception of their age in a way that fits brand identity or to promote products or services by directing the focus to well-being determinants. Accettazione del research paper dal titolo “Il turismo da crociera come opportunità di sviluppo territoriale: uno studio esplorativo” (coautori: Giovanni Pino, Alessandro Peluso, Carla Tomacelli, Gianluigi Guido) al XXIV Convegno Annuale di Sinergie, presso il Dipartimento di Scienze dell’Economia, Università del Salento, Lecce. 18-19 ottobre 2012. Abstract della ricerca: Il turismo da crociera è un settore potenzialmente idoneo a rafforzare l’economia di un territorio avente vocazione turistica. Questo studio si è proposto di identificare i fattori che possono facilitare lo sviluppo di questo settore e le condizioni attraverso cui esso può apportare dei benefici all’economia locale. Sono state condotte venti interviste semi-strutturate nelle provincie di Brindisi e Lecce. Ogni intervista è stata registrata su supporto audio e trascritta in un momento successivo. Le trascrizioni sono state sottoposte ad un’analisi dei contenuti al fine di categorizzare le risposte ottenute. È stato appurato che lo sviluppo simultaneo del turismo da crociera e dell’economia di una destinazione turistica è ricollegabile principalmente all’adeguamento infrastrutturale del territorio, alla creazione di alleanze pubblico-private tra gli operatori del settore, alla predisposizione di adeguate azioni di marketing territoriale. I risultati ottenuti possono essere limitatamente estesi ad altre destinazioni turistiche. Il campione esaminato, in particolare, dovrebbe essere ampliato ai responsabili di compagnie di crociera localizzati al di fuori dei confini nazionali. Questo studio suggerisce che, per favorire lo sviluppo di un territorio tramite il turismo da crociera, gli operatori locali dovrebbero considerare gli investimenti in infrastrutture, servizi turistici ed iniziative di marketing come una priorità. Le compagnie di crociera, dal canto loro, dovrebbero cooperare attivamente con le imprese e gli enti pubblici locali. Il presente studio ha esaminato un’area d’indagine fondamentalmente inesplorata a livello accademico e contribuisce alla letteratura sui sistemi territoriali locali e sul marketing territoriale. Si allega programma e paper. Il paper è stato pubblicato nei seguenti proceedings: “Il turismo da crociera come opportunità di sviluppo territoriale: uno studio esplorativo” in "Il territorio come giacimento di vitalità per l'impresa", 2Conference proceedings: XXIV Convegno annuale di Sinergie2, 2012, pp. 373-383 (ISBN: 978-88-907394-0-8).

Partecipazione come relatore per la presentazione del paper di ricerca dal titolo “Attenzione oculare e riconoscimento della marca: il fenomeno del ‘mix-and-match’ nella moda” (“Mix-and-Match Fashion Trend and Luxury Brand Recognition: An Empirical Test Using Eye-Tracking”) (coautori: Gianluigi Guido, Carla Tomacelli, Antonio Mileti, Irene Prete, Alessandro Peluso, Anna Longo), al Convegno internazionale “International Marketing Trends Conference”, Parigi, Francia. 17-19 gennaio 2013. ISBN: 9782953281125. Si allega: - Certificato di partecipazione come relatore - Programma del Convegno - Paper presentato Abstract della ricerca: In questa ricerca, due esperimenti condotti con l’eye-tracking mostrano come l’abilità del consumatore nel riconoscere le marche moda di lusso aumenti quando vi è una comparazione tra prodotti di tali marche con quelli di marche, al contrario, del fast fashion (cioè che “riproducono” i trend di stagione con abiti molto simili a quelli delle marche di lusso ma a prezzi molto più accessibili). Inoltre, l’analisi dell’attenzione del consumatore attraverso la tecnologia dell’eye-tracking evidenzia che, tra i diversi elementi stilistici, il riconoscimento è particolarmente facilitato dalla presenza di accessori (vale a dire, borse e scarpe). I risultati dimostrano che il trend di consumo definito come “mix-and-match” (cioè la combinazione di marche del lusso con marche più di massa) offre alle aziende della moda di lusso l’opportunità di migliorare il riconoscimento della propria marca attraverso gli accessori e che, contrariamente a quanto si possa pensare, l’abbinamento con marche fast fashion incrementa la riconoscibilità delle marche del lusso. Le implicazioni manageriali possono essere diverse, ma in particolare, tali risultati possono supportare i marketing manager nel migliorare l’efficacia sia dei piani collezione che delle campagne pubblicitarie.

Accettazione del research paper dal titolo “Does popularity in social networks influence purchasing and lifestyle decisions? The meaning of online friendship” (coautori: Gianluigi Guido, Claudia Barbarito) al “X Convegno Nazionale della Società Italiana Marketing (SIM)”, “Smart Life: dall’innovazione tecnologica”, Milano, Università Bicocca. 3-4 ottobre 2013. Abstract della ricerca: Nowadays, millions of people use social network sites (SNSs) to communicate with each other, but little is known about the real effects that online popularity (i.e., the number of friends on a SNS) has on users’ behaviors. This paper explores the social influence of SNSs and demonstrates that the number of online friends on an SNS does not influence its users’ purchasing and lifestyle choices. This study also reveals that low-popular users (i.e., users with few friends on a SNS) are influenced by the intensity of their perceived friendships (i.e., how strong they perceive their relations with their online friends). On the contrary, high-popular users (i.e., users with many friends on a SNS) are influenced by their online friends’ perceived coolness (i.e., how cool they consider their online friends), and, in particular, the influence on purchasing decisions increases with the value of products they intend to buy. Results shed light on a new meaning of the term “friendship” on a SNS, which is substantially different from what is common in offline contexts: this new construct, which we call “Friendoolness”, can be intended as a mix of friendship and coolness and it is mainly based on showing up how many cool friends one has. Accettazione del research paper “Aging and Product Choice: The Effects of Feel-Age and Social Context” (Coautori: Alessandro Peluso, Carolyn Yoon, Gianluigi Guido) alla Conferenza Internazionale “Association for Consumer Research (ACR) North American Conference”, Baltimora, Maryland, USA. 23-26 Ottobre 2014. Paper pubblicato nell’Advances in Consumer Research (allegato): Back to Fun, Vol. 42, J. Cotte and S. Wood (Eds.), 2014, Association for Consumer Research, Duluth (MN): 108-109. ISBN: 9780915552740. Abstract della ricerca: Older adults tend to state they feel younger than they actually are, and thus report a feel-age that is systematically lower than their chronological age. The present research investigates the extent to which this tendency is malleable as a function of social context. We find an exaggerated tendency by older consumers to state younger feel-ages when they are exposed to social cues from young people, as compared to old (i.e., same aged) people (studies 1 and 2). This effect is mediated by the decreased sense of harmony with the surrounding environment that is experienced by older consumers when others in their contexts are young. This reduced sense of harmony, in turn, magnifies the discrepancy between the reported feel-age and actual chronological age (study 2). The final study examines the downstream consequences of this phenomenon in a consumer domain: when exposed to young (versus old) social cues, older consumers choose more contemporary products that are typically more preferred by younger consumers (study 3). Accettazione del research paper dal titolo “How to Make Better Consumers in Luxury: The Role of Shame and Empathy” (Coautori: Matteo De Angelis, Alessandro Peluso, Isabella Soscia, Richard Bagozzi, Gianluigi Guido) al Convegno Internazionale “2015 Academy of Marketing Science (AMS) World Marketing Congress, Rediscovering the Essentiality of Marketing”, Bari. 14-18 luglio 2015. Abstract della ricerca: Aiming to understand underlying mechanisms behind consumers’ choice of sustainable products, in this study we consider two different and opposite types of communication about luxury products, which we label sustainability-oriented (whereby a message communicates the positive achievements related to the purchase of sustainable products) and unsustainability-oriented communication (whereby the message communicates the bad outputs related to the purchase of unsustainable products). Our goal is to detect when one versus the other type of communication is more effective in increasing consumers’ preference for sustainable products. We pursue this goal by exploring the role of emotions, which might play a relevant role in luxury goods consumer behavior. Indeed, emotion seem to be a very central factor since luxury is related to social distinction, self-enhancement, dreams and high emotional values, as well as sustainability is related to the relationship between the self and others. Indeed, in social psychology self-conscious emotions concern a group of emotions that are strongly connected with the self; these emotions are activated by an intentional focus on the self and have implications on the way the individual experiences and values the self. In addition, when customers are exposed to communication content, information processing occurs (Jackson 2004), and if this information is processed in a relatively automatic and intuitive way, heuristic information processing takes place. In this sense, communication can be either classified as “thinking” or “emotional”; the first one normally contains information requiring significant cognitive processing, the second instead is designed to trigger specific emotional reactions, at least initially. As a consequence, in assessing the effectiveness of different types of communications related to luxury goods and sustainability, emotions may represent the underlying variables explaining specific consumption behaviors. Accettazione del paper “An Empirical Analysis of the WOM Extremeness in Controversial Topics” (coautori: Matteo De Angelis, Vito Tassiello, Michele Costabile) al Convegno Internazionale “6th EMAC Regional Conference - Marketing Theory Challenges in Emerging Markets”, WU (Vienna University of Economics and Business) Vienna, Austria. 16-18 settembre 2015. Abstract della ricerca: We investigate the effect of controversy of topics on WOM extremeness. Across three experiments we show that highly versus lowly controversial topics lead people to take more extreme positions and to share such extreme positions in their conversations with others. We provide empirical evidence for the role of individuals’ chronic need for uniqueness as a moderating factor, and for the role of both individuals’ interest in the topic at hand and individuals’ perceptions about how interesting to share their opinion is as mediators. Accettazione del paper di ricerca dal titolo “Lingua Franca Narratives of Ancient and Modern Odysseys Across the Mediterranean Sea: An Experiential-Linguistic Approach to the Marketing of Responsible Tourism” (coautori: Maria Grazia Guido, Lucia Errico, Pietro L. Iaia) al Convegno Internazionale “Tourism Across Cultures: Accessibility in Tourist Communication”, Lecce, Italia. 25-27 febbraio 2016. Abstract della ricerca: This paper introduces an interdisciplinary research exploring the emotional experience of Italian seaside resorts whose geographical position in the Southern Mediterranean coasts has always determined their destiny as places of hospitality and hybridization of languages and cultures. A cognitive-pragmatic model of Experiential Linguistics and some strategies of Experiential Place Marketing will be applied to the ‘emotional promotion’ of Responsible Tourism in order to enquire into the effects of emotions upon the tourists’ perception of the holiday as an experience of ‘personal and cultural growth’. This is expected to develop from their appraisal of (a) non-western migrants’ dramatic narrations of journeys across the sea, reported in their variations of English as a ‘lingua franca’ (ELF), and (b) epic narratives of Mediterranean ‘odysseys’ towards ‘Utopian destinations’ belonging to the western cultural heritage, translated from ancient (Greek and Latin) into modern ELF variations. The target of the marketing plan are tourists playing the role of ‘intercultural mediators’ with migrants in one of the seaside resorts of Salento, a southern-Italian area affected by migrant arrivals. To facilitate the tourists’ process of ‘experiential embodiment’ of past and present dramatic sea voyages, the cultural project of Responsible Tourism is designed to introduce tourists and migrants to an ‘Ethnopoetic analysis’ of two corpora of modern and ancient oral sea voyage narratives – the former collected during ethnographic fieldworks in reception centres for refugees, and the latter including extracts from Homer’s Odyssey and Virgil’s Aeneid. The purpose is to directly involve tourists and migrants as if they were ‘philologists’ and ‘ethnographers’ exploring how such ancient and modern oral narratives are organized into spontaneous ‘verse structures’ reproducing the sequences and rhythms of human actions and emotions in response to the traumatic experience of violent natural phenomena which, through the use of ergative syntactic structures, become metaphorically personified as mythological monsters, or as objects and elements endowed with an autonomous, dynamic force capable of destroying the human beings at their mercy. The Ethnopoetic analysis and translation, together with the subsequent multimodal rendering of such journey narratives for place-marketing purposes aim at making both tourists and migrants aware of the common socio-cultural values of the different populations that have produced them. Accettazione del research paper dal titolo “Similar to Myself or to the Green? The Effect of Introducing Different Types of Green New Products on Luxury Brand Evaluation and Purchase Intention” (coautori:, Feray Adiguzel, Matteo De Angelis) al Convegno Internazionale “2016 Monaco Symposium on Luxury, Emerging Challenges in Luxury Marketing”, presso la International University of Monaco (IUM), Monte-Carlo. 7-8 Aprile 2016. Abstract della ricerca: Luxury companies’ increasing commitment toward sustainability, alongside luxury consumers’ growing attention toward environmental issues, substantiate the notion that luxury and sustainability are compatible concepts. However, academic research suggests that sustainable luxury is still perceived by consumers as a contradiction. This article thus investigates the type of environmental sustainability practices that luxury companies should adopt in order to galvanize consumers’ interest in sustainable versions of their products. In particular, we analyze the differential effectiveness of two strategies that luxury companies might adopt when introducing green new products: First, the green product might be similar in design to a luxury company’s established, non-green products. Second, the green product might be similar in design to models made by non-luxury companies specializing in green products. The results from three experiments show that these two strategies can be differentially effective depending on both consumer-related and product-related factors. L'attività di ricerca del sottoscritto si è focalizzata sui seguenti filoni di ricerca: a) The dimensions of luxury fashion brands in Argentina; b) The social role of luxury in Argentina; c) Social responsibility for clothing purchasing; d) Imagery and brand personality in fashion advertising strategies; e) Cross-cultural studies for the comparison of consumption motives, values and attitudes toward the luxury fashion concept (Argentina vs Italy); f) Determinants of purchasing intention for fashion luxury goods in the Argentinian market. I suddetti studi preliminari rientrano nell’ambito delle attività svolte durante il periodo in cui il sottosctitto è stato componente (da marzo 2012 a dicembre 2012), come Visiting Researcher e Visiting Professor, del suddetto centro di ricerca presso la IAE Universidad Austral di Buenos Aires. Responsabile della ricerca scientifica affidatami dalla University of Hertfordshire, Hatfield, Regno Unito. L’affidamento è stato formalizzato con un contratto di Visiting Researcher con la stessa University of Hertfordshire (periodo: 15 giugno 2015-15 settembre 2015). Il progetto è stato sviluppato dopo diversi incontri del sottoscritto a Londra con la Prof.ssa Sue Halliday (Professor of Marketing, University of Hertfordshire, Hatfield, United Kingdom). Il progetto ha avuto l'obiettivo di studiare la percezione del marchio “Made in Britain” in Italia. Più in particolare, il progetto di ricerca è stato volto ad individuare come il Made in Britain è stato percepito in Italia in due determinati periodi storici (gli anni ‘60 e gli anni ‘70), considerando due settori: la moda e la musica. Il metodo utilizzato è stato di tipo quali-quantitativo, con analisi dei contenuti (immagini e testi) di diversi numeri di riviste specializzate pubblicati nei decenni oggetto di studio. Questo materiale è stato reperito consultando diversi archivi. Inoltre, per il presente progetto di ricerca sono stati raccolti anche dati primari attraverso interviste condotte a rappresentanti di marchi leader durante i due decenni analizzati. Infine, è stata svolta anche un'analisi di dati secondari, sul settore musica, relativi agli anni '60 e '70. La ricerca ha evidenziato interessanti risultati con implicazioni sia di tipo teorico (con contributi alla letteratura di “Made in” e “country of origin”) che di tipo manageriale (in riferimento alle strategie di international branding). Allo sviluppo della ricerca ha dato un importante contributo il Prof. Matteo De Angelis (LUISS University). Il lavoro ha portato alla produzione di un research paper dal titolo “Historical and contemporary resonances of the 'Made in Britain' label in Italy” attualmente in fase di peer-review da parte dell’International Marketing Review. Abstract della ricerca: This paper provides a rich resource of insight into how perception of period specific “made-in” values evolves across subsequent historical periods. In particular, the goal is to discuss how the British “Swinging Sixties” have been perceived in Italy over the following two decades, namely 1965-1975 and 1975-1985. Qualitative analysis of mainly secondary sources, such as relevant issues of important Italian fashion and music magazines. Findings of this research show that the “Made in Britain” label across the 20-year period from 1965 to 1985 in Italy was characterized by specific values that were also malleable and in evolution. This study focuses on only two specific countries (Britain and Italy) and made-in values associated with one specific period (the British Sixties). International marketing managers can now communicate country of origin/brand origin to benefit from key values as perceived at peak periods of appeal. This study demonstrates that perceptions about “made-in” values that describe a country in a given period evolve over time, thus offering companies the possibility to leverage those values in different ways over different periods. This historical perspective enables us to demonstrate that authenticity and temporality are key elements of “made-in” values such that theorists and international managers may benefit from leveraging both. Si allegano: - Affidamento progetto di ricerca; - Condizioni offerta incarico; - Job description; - - Paper della ricerca svolta, attualmente in fase di peer-review all’International Marketing Review.

Incarico di ricerca nella posizione di Visiting Scholar presso la Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, USA (5 agosto 2013 – 8 settembre 2013). Durante il visiting il sottoscritto ha lavorato sia sull’analisi della letteratura e quindi sul perfezionamento dei fondamentali teorici della ricerca sia sul design di diversi esperimenti condotti nella Ross School of Business, in laboratorio oppure online. Inoltre, durante il periodo di visiting è stato possibile entrare in contatto con diversi studiosi della Ross School of Business e questo ha permesso di affinare determinate conoscenze tecniche sia sul tema sia sugli strumenti di raccolta dati ed analisi degli stessi. Durante il periodo di ricerca presso la Ross School of Business il sottoscritto è stato anche chiamato a presentare il suddetto progetto di ricerca in due seminari interni al dipartimento di marketing ed aventi come audience i PhD students di Marketing della Ross School, con il fine di avviare un dibattito con loro sulla ricerca e presentarla come esempio di sviluppo di un modello concettuale. Il progetto ha poi coinvolto anche il Prof. Alessandro Peluso ed il Prof. Gianluigi Guido dell’Università del Salento, Lecce. Il lavoro iniziato con la Prof. ssa Carolyn Yoon durante il visiting è poi stato presentato l’anno successivo (nel 2014) come prima versione di research paper alla Association for Consumer Research (ACR) North American Conference (Baltimora, Maryland, USA, 23-26 ottobre 2014) e pubblicato nell’Advances in Consumer Research: Back to Fun, Vol. 42, edito da J. Cotte e S. Wood (Eds.), 2014, Association for Consumer Research, Duluth (MN): 108-109. ISBN: 9780915552740. La versione finale del paper è attualmente al suo second-round review per il Journal of Consumer Research. Molto importante durante il periodo di visiting è stata la conoscenza personale con il Prof. Richard Bagozzi (Full Professor di Marketing, Dwight F. Benton Professor of Behavioral Science in Management, Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, USA, E-mail: bagozzi@umich.edu), il quale ha dato un contribuito al miglioramento del progetto e con il quale il sottoscritto ha poi iniziato a sviluppare nuovi progetti di ricerca. Si allegano: - Lettera di invito da parte del Dipartimento di Marketing della University of Michigan, come Visiting Scholar, firmato dal Prof. Puneet Manchanda (Area Chair, Marketing, Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, USA); - Lettera del Prof. Richard Bagozzi sul lavoro di ricerca svolto dal sottoscritto durante il Visiting presso la University of Michigan; - Lettera della Prof.ssa Carolyn Yoon sul lavoro di ricerca svolto dal sottoscritto durante il Visiting presso la University of Michigan; - Copia del paper della ricerca attualmente in fase di second-round review per il Journal of Consumer Research.

Incarico di ricerca come Visiting Scholar presso la Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, USA (19 maggio 2014 – 20 giugno 2014). Il periodo di ricerca come visiting scholar presso la University of Michigan ha permesso di iniziare un nuovo progetto di ricerca con il Prof. Richard Bagozzi (Full Professor di Marketing, Dwight F. Benton Professor of Behavioral Science in Management, Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, USA, E-mail: bagozzi@umich.edu). In particolare, il periodo di visiting è servito a sviluppare un progetto di ricerca sul tema del green marketing; specificatamente sul ruolo della valenza del message framing e delle emozioni nell'attivazione di determinati comportamenti pro-environmental dei consumatori. La ricerca avviata, pertanto, studia i meccanismi emozionali sottostanti l'effetto della valenza del message framing (per esempio nelle pubblicità) sui comportamenti dei consumatori, investigandone anche le potenziali variabili moderatrici. Le variabili di moderazione studiate sono state quelle della tipologia di prodotto (status-signaling vs. non-status-signaling) e del "concern for the environment" dei consumatori. Durante il periodo di visiting il sottoscritto ha partecipato ad una conferenza tenutasi presso la Ross School dal titolo “The Psychology of Design” e si è confrontato con altri studiosi della Ross School specializzati sul tema della sostenibilità (per esempio con il prof. Andrew J. Hoffman, Director, Erb Institute Holcim, Professor of Sustainable Enterprise, Ross School of Business/SNRE University of Michigan). Successivamente, nel progetto sono stati coinvolti anche la Prof. ssa Isabella Soscia (SKEMA Business School, Francia), il Prof Alessandro Peluso (Università del Salento, Lecce), ed il Prof. Matteo De Angelis (Università LUISS Guido Carli, Roma). La ricerca avviata con il Prof. Bagozzi ha portato alla scrittura di una prima draft del paper finale presentata l’anno successivo (nel 2015) all’Academy of Marketing Science (AMS) World Marketing Congress, Rediscovering the Essentiality of Marketing (Bari, 14-18 luglio 2015). Una seconda versione della ricerca, in uno stadio più avanzato, è stata, nell’Ottobre dello stesso 2015, presentata all’Association for Consumer Research North American Conference 2015 – Advancing Connections (New Orleans, LA, USA. 1-4 ottobre 2015). Il paper in versione finale è attualmente in fase di submission al Journal of Business Ethics. Il Prof. Bagozzi, avendo avuto un ruolo di advisor sul progetto, soprattutto nella fase iniziale, ha preferito non essere inserito tra gli autori del paper inviato al Journal of Business Ethics. Le attività di ricerca di questo gruppo, per i seguenti lavori, sono iniziate nel 2013. • Titolo della ricerca: “Luxury advertising and recognizable artworks: New insights on the ‘art infusion’ effect” European Journal of Marketing” (coautori: G. Pino, A. Peluso, G. Guido). Paper finale mandato allo European Journal of Marketing ed attualmente in fase di 1st round review (si allega copia del paper) Abstract della ricerca: This research advances current knowledge about art infusion, that is, art’s ability to increase the perceived prestige of luxury products, by focusing on the usage of artworks evocative of their creators’ most recognizable style in luxury advertising. The research is structured in three studies conducted online and in a real consumption situation. The first study explores the effect of the recognizability of a painter’s style on consumers’ product judgments. The second and third studies explore the moderating roles of desire to signal status and desire for distinction, which are relevant to advertisers interested in targeting these individual differences through their campaigns. Advertisements that incorporate artworks evocative of a painter’s most recognizable style enhance the advertised products’ perceived luxuriousness. Consumers with a higher desire to signal status exhibit greater purchasing intention in response to recognizable artworks. • Titolo della ricerca: “The Effect of Product Touch on Consumers’ Responses to Tactile-Informative and Tactile-Pleasing Products” (coautori: G. Pino, M. De Angelis, A. Peluso, G. Guido). Paper finale in preparazione per la submission all’International Journal of Research in Marketing (si allega working paper) Abstract della ricerca: This research examines the effect of product touch on consumers’ responses toward two types of products: tactile-informative products, which consumers touch mainly to acquire practical information about their characteristics, and tactile-pleasing products, which consumers touch mainly to experience pleasing haptic sensations. Six experimental studies show that allowing consumers to touch these two types of products has positive consequences on their attitudes and purchase intentions, albeit through two distinct mechanisms. In particular, touching tactile-informative products exerts a positive effect on consumers’ responses via the perceived ease of using such products, while touching tactile-pleasing products exerts the same effect via sensory enjoyment. Importantly, these two effects are moderated by two different dimensions of consumers’ need for touch. • Titolo della ricerca: “Determinants of Apulian Households’ Intention to Adopt Energy Efficiency Measures in Residential Buildings” (in collaborazione, oltre che con G. Pino, A. Peluso e G. Guido, anche con M. Irene Prete, Luigi Piper, Cristian Rizzo, Mauro Capestro, Antonio Mileti e Marco Pichierri, Università del Salento). Paper mandato al Journal of Cleaner Production ed in fase di 1st round review (si allega copia del paper) Abstract della ricerca The present research adopts an extended version of the Theory of Planned Behavior (Ajzen, 1991) – which includes attitude, subjective norms, perceived behavioral control, and environmental concern – to investigate the antecedents of households’ intention to adopt and willingness to pay for Energy Efficiency Measures (EEMs). The results show that attitude is the main determinant of households’ intention to adopt and willingness to pay for EEMs. However, subjective norms, perceived behavioral control, and environmental concern have their own positive effects based on the income level, education, and age of household subgroups.

Direzione, insieme al Prof. Alessandro Peluso (Università del Salento), del seguente gruppo di ricerca internazionale: Cesare Amatulli (Università degli Studi di Bari Aldo Moro), Alessandro Peluso (Università del Salento), Carolyn Yoon (Full Professor of Marketing, University of Michigan), Gianluigi Guido (Ordinario, Università del Salento). In particolare, questo gruppo di ricerca è caratterizzatp dalla collaborazione con la Prof.ssa Carolyn Yoon (Full Professor of Marketing, Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, USA, E-mail: yoonc@umich.edu). La collaborazione con la Prof.ssa C. Yoon è stata avviata dal sottoscritto nel 2013 durante il periodo di Visiting Scholar presso la Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, Stati Uniti. La direzione del presente gruppo di ricerca ha permesso di sviluppare un importante progetto di ricerca dal titolo “Older Consumers Feeling and Behaving Younger: The Effects of Social Context” ed avente per oggetto lo studio degli effetti del contesto sociale sulla percezione dell'età cognitiva e, di conseguenza, sulle scelte d’acquisto degli older consumers. Un primo articolo preliminare basato su questa ricerca è stato presentato al convegno internazionale dell’Association for Consumer Research, tenutosi a Baltimora (USA) dal 23 al 26 ottobre 2014. Citazione dei proceeding pubblicati: “Aging and Product Choice: The Effects of Feel-Age and Social Context” (C. Amatulli, A. Peluso, C. Yoon, G. Guido), Advances in Consumer Research: Back to Fun,Vol. 42, J. Cotte and S. Wood (Eds.), 2014, Association for Consumer Research, Duluth (MN): 108-109. Proceedings of the Association for Consumer Research (ACR) North American Conference, Baltimore (MD), October 23rd-26th 2014. ISBN: 9780915552740. Il paper finale, frutto del lavoro di ricerca di questo gruppo, è in fase di seconda revisione (II round review) per la rivista Journal of Consumer Research (si allega copia del paper). Abstract della ricerca: Older consumers exhibit a systematic tendency to feel younger than their chronological age. We investigate the malleability of this tendency and its underlying mechanisms by focusing on how social context influences older consumers’ feel-age. In particular, we examine the role of social cues—whether others in the environment are young versus old—and the effects on downstream consumption behavior. Across six studies, we provide empirical evidence that older consumers’ tendency to feel younger reflects an effort by older consumers to identify with young people while distancing themselves from the less desirable category of older people. We find that the presence of young (vs. old) social cues magnifies older consumers’ tendency to feel younger (studies 1A and 1B, and study 2). However, such an effect is attenuated when the young social cues are presented in a less desirable fashion (study 3) and when older consumers have higher self-esteem (study 4 and study 5). Moreover, the exaggerated tendency to feel younger is especially pronounced among older consumers with low self-esteem, and mediates the increased desire for contemporary over traditional products (study 4 and study 5). The theoretical and practical implications are discussed.

Direzione delle attività di ricerca del seguente gruppo di ricerca: Cesare Amatulli (Università degli Studi di Bari Aldo Moro), Matteo De Angelis (Università LUISS Guido Carli, Roma), Gianluigi Guido (Università del Salento), Dott. Marco Pichierri (Università di Bologna). Il lavoro di ricerca svolto dal suddetto gruppo ha permesso di sviluppare una ricerca sul ruolo della pubblicità nel marketing del lusso e sulle differenze, in termini di contenuti e stili, tra la pubblicità nell'alto di gamma e la pubblicità nel mass market. In particolare, la ricerca ha prodotto un paper dal titolo “The importance of dreams in advertising: luxury versus mass market”, attualmente in fase di perfezionamento per la submission allo European Management Journal (si allega working paper). Abstract della ricerca: Luxury companies commonly use imagery rather than text in their print advertising as a way of allowing customers to assign their own personal meanings to the message, thus fulfilling their desire to dream. Indeed, in this current era of information proliferation, today’s consumers are increasingly less willing to process advertising information they receive as text. We thus propose that mass market companies must more widely adopt the practice of using dream-evoking communication in order to appeal to modern consumers. To substantiate this position, we conducted an exploratory study with some luxury companies’ print advertisements. Based on the results, we present mass market managers with suggestions about how to employ the luxury model to make their communications more aspirational than rational through imagery rather than text.

Il suddetto gruppo ha lavorato su un progetto di ricerca finalizzato alla pubblicazione della monografia (in inglese) dal titolo “Sustainable Luxury Brands. Evidence from Research and Implications for Managers” (ISBN: 978-1-137-60158-2) edito dall'editore inglese Palgrave Macmillan nell'ambito della serie/collana “Palgrave Advances in Luxury Series”. Le attività del gruppo di ricerca sono iniziate nel settembre del 2013. Nella fase iniziale di sviluppo del progetto è stata determinante l’esperienza di ricerca del sottoscritto negli Stati Uniti; in particolare, le collaborazioni con il Prof. Richard Bagozzi (Full Professor of Marketing, Ross School of Business, University of Michigan, USA) e l'incontro con il Prof. Philip Kotler (Full Professor of Marketing, Kellogg School of Management, Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois), esponenti di elevato prestigio nella comunità scientifica internazionale di marketing e dei quali la monografia include rispettivamente una presentazione (“Foreward”) ed un “Endorsement”. Breve abstract sui contenuti del libro: This book contends that luxury and sustainability can successfully co-exist. The authors support this claim, with a consumer perspective, focusing on sustainable brands in different industries – from luxury versus mass market. They give a comprehensive overview of how luxury can be considered “inherently” sustainable, because of some of its key-characteristics (such as craftsmanship, preservation of artisan skills, product quality, durability, and limited quantities of goods). By presenting lots of examples and real case-studies, they provide new insights into current and upcoming topics in luxury research.

I lavori di questo gruppo di ricerca sono stati avviati nel 2013 per la realizzazione di diversi progetti di ricerca, tra i quali si evidenziano: Progetto di ricerca dal titolo: “An Investigation of How Language Abstractness Affects Service Referral Persuasiveness”. Paper pubblicato sulla rivista Journal of Business Research. Abstract della ricerca: Due to the inherent risk and uncertainty characterizing pre-purchase service evaluation, consumers tend to rely on referrals from other consumer swho already have experiences with that service. Thus, companies are eager to stimulate such referrals and improve their effectiveness. To this end, this research investigates how consumers' linguistic framing of service recommendations influences recipients' attitudes and behavioral intentions. Specifically, this study focuses on one key dimension of language—its abstractness (vs. concreteness)—and hypothesizes that the effect of language abstractness on referral persuasiveness depends on recipients' prior knowledge about the service in question. The results of two experiments in the context of financial and medical services demonstrate that abstract language is more effective than concrete language for recipients with high prior knowledge. Moreover, this research shows that recipients' engagement in mental imagery processing is that makes abstract language more effective for those with high prior knowledge. This articles ends with a discussion of the study's implications for academic research, social communication and service management, along with its limitations and future research directions. Il paper di questa ricerca, in versione aggiornata, è stato successivamente mandato al Journal of Interactive Marketing dove è attualmente in fase di peer-review (si allega working paper).
